questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough for the past 6 months. He also reports fatigue and difficulty swallowing solid foods. In cold weather, his fingers often turn blue and become painful. He occasionally smokes cigarettes on weekends. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mm Hg. The skin over his trunk and arms is thickened and tightened. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally over the lower lung fields on auscultation. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient with diffuse SSc is at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Right-sided filling pressures increase as a result of pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload. An increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is thus likely to ensue.

B) INCORRECT:

Restrictive lung diseases increase the elastic recoil of lungs and impair their ability to expand, thus causing decreased lung compliance. This patient with diffuse SSc likely has restrictive lung disease and, therefore, decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

C) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is caused by collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli, which interferes with their ability to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries, resulting in decreased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity of the lungs (DLCO). Manifestations of ILD include progressive exertional dyspnea, chronic nonproductive cough, and inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Pulmonary involvement (e.g., ILD, pulmonary arterial hypertension, lung cancer) is the leading cause of death in patients with diffuse SSc.

D) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance, which is the resistance of the pulmonary tree to airflow during inspiration and expiration, is a parameter for airway obstruction and is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. As SSc causes restrictive lung disease, airway resistance is not affected.

E) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. While the A-a gradient is normal in cases of hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when ventilation-perfusion mismatch, shunting, and limited diffusion occur. This patient with signs and symptoms of diffuse SSc is at risk of pulmonary fibrosis, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.
questions.hint: The combination of pulmonary symptoms, dysphagia, Raynaud phenomenon, and sclerotic skin raises concern for diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), which frequently causes interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of progressive shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. Pulmonary examination shows bibasilar inspiratory crackles. An x-ray of the chest shows multiple nodular opacities in the upper lobes and calcified hilar nodules. Pulmonary functions tests show an FEV1:FVC ratio of 80% and a severely decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide. A biopsy specimen of a lung nodule shows weakly birefringent needles surrounded by concentric layers of hyalinized collagen. The patient has most likely been exposed to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Berylliosis is typically seen in patients working in high-tech sectors, such as the nuclear and aerospace industries, where beryllium alloys are common. While berylliosis also affects the upper lobes and would present similarly to this patient, histological analysis is characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas and a reticular interstitial pattern on chest x-ray similar to that of sarcoidosis.

B) CORRECT:

This patient is suffering from chronic silicosis due to an occupational exposure to crystalline silica, as evidenced by the pathognomic biopsy findings that are consistent with a silicotic nodule. Radiographic abnormalities, such as diffuse ground glass or nodular opacities, can arise early in the disease (typically the upper lobes). However, overt symptoms can take decades of exposure to develop, which is consistent with this patient's advanced age.

Advanced silicosis patients are at particularly high risk for developing tuberculosis.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view) of a man with occupational exposure to stone dust who presented with chronic dyspnea

There are multiple nodular opacities present, predominantly in the upper lobes of the lungs (examples indicated by arrowheads). The nodules have conglomerated to form irregular masses (green overlay). The diaphragmatic domes are abnormally elevated indicating fibrosis (indicated by lines and arrows), which is visible as linear opacities adjacent to the shadow of the base of the heart (yellow overlay). The mediastinum is widened, indicating hilar lymphadenopathy.

Diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Exposure to thermophilic actinomyces spores in moldy hay can lead to a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis, called Farmer's lung. This would also present with progressive dyspnea and chronic cough, but histology would instead reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells. Furthermore, chest x-ray would show ground-glass opacities with honeycombing, and in some cases, emphysema.
Image Description:

H&E stain: There is a circumscribed granuloma (green area) of lymphocytes and multinucleated giant cells (red areas) on the left below the bronchus (Br), which are a characteristic indication of hypersensitivity pneumonitis. (Alv = alveolus, B = blood vessel)

D) INCORRECT:

Chronic exposure to carbon dust can result in Coal worker's pneumoconiosis. Similar to this patient's condition, black lung results in small nodular opacities on chest x-ray, specifically in the upper lung fields. Histologic analysis, however, would instead show deposition of dark pigment in the interstitial tissue and hilar lymph nodes due to carbon accumulation in alveolar macrophages.

E) INCORRECT:

Exposure to asbestos fibers can lead to development of asbestosis later in life. While asbestosis also presents indolently with dyspnea and a chronic cough, the chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages.
questions.hint: The patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, and decreased DLCO raise suspicion for an interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, together with the upper lobe nodular opacities and calcified hilar lymph nodes, are characteristic of exposure to a substance classically associated with hard rock mining.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician for worsening fatigue and dyspnea for several months. She has not been seen by a physician in 10 years. She is also concerned about the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the patient's nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

E) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.

F) INCORRECT:

Although advanced COPD is a cause of chronic hypoxia, it does not cause digital clubbing. The reasons for this are unknown. The presence of digital clubbing in a patient with COPD is concerning for an underlying lung carcinoma. Although COPD can cause dyspnea, this patient does not present with its pathognomic features (e.g., ≥ 3 months of chronic productive cough in 2 consecutive years).
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Cardiopulmonary examination shows fine inspiratory crackles bilaterally. There is clubbing present in the fingers bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) show an FVC of 78% of expected and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A bronchial asthma exacerbation could cause this patient's shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. However, auscultation during an asthma exacerbation typically reveals end-expiratory wheezes rather than fine inspiratory crackles, and clubbing is not a characteristic finding in patients with asthma. In addition, this patient's PFTs are not typical of an obstructive lung disease such as an asthma exacerbation. Lastly, imaging of the chest in asthma shows signs of hyperinflation and air trapping, which are not seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can also manifest with shortness of breath, cough, and crackles on lung exam. However, clubbing is not a typical feature, and this patient does not have other symptoms of sarcoidosis (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss) or any extrapulmonary findings of the disease (e.g., arthritis, anterior uveitis, erythema nodosum). In addition, while sarcoidosis can, in rare cases, manifest with a similar PFT pattern, normal findings are more common. Lastly, chest imaging in sarcoidosis is more likely to show extensive bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is not seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given his PFTs, imaging results, shortness of breath, persistent nonproductive cough, and bilateral fine inspiratory crackles, and clubbing (which suggests chronic hypoxia). PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis most commonly show a pattern typical of restrictive lung disease, and the honeycombing seen on this patient's CT scan is also consistent with this diagnosis. Pulmonary fibrosis is most commonly idiopathic but can also be associated with certain risk factors, such as medication use (e.g., methotrexate, bleomycin, amiodarone), connective tissue disease (e.g., scleroderma), and environmental exposures (e.g., silicosis, coal dust exposure).

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis can occur in various forms, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, and invasive aspergillosis. Aspergillosis is rare, and this patient does not have any reported risk factors associated with aspergillosis (e.g., immunosuppression, preexisting lung disease), which makes this diagnosis very unlikely. In addition, PFTs in patients with ABPA typically show signs of obstructive lung disease, rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may develop pulmonary hypertension as a result of his underlying condition, pulmonary hypertension alone would not cause this patient's symptoms, clinical findings, PFT abnormalities, and imaging study results.

F) INCORRECT:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis can cause shortness of breath, cough, clubbing, and crackles on lung exam. However, this patient does not have any other symptoms of active TB (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats), nor does he have any noted risk factors (e.g., immunosuppression, exposure history). Imaging findings associated with active TB include consolidation, hilar lymphadenopathy, effusions, and cavitary lung lesions, none of which are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Active pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) typically manifests with systemic (e.g., low-grade fever, night sweats, weight loss, decreased appetite, and malaise) and pulmonary symptoms (e.g., dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain due to pleural effusion, productive cough, and possibly hemoptysis in advanced stages).
Symptomatic TB can occur as a result of primary infection (primary active TB) or reactivation of latent infection (reactivation TB). While symptoms are similar in both conditions, radiographic presentation differs.
Radiographic imaging in primary TB commonly shows a Ghon complex (Ghon focus with its associated lymph node), unilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and homogenous consolidation with ill-defined borders in the middle and lower lobes. Chest x-ray in reactivation TB typically shows multiple cavities in the upper lobes, calcifications, patchy consolidations, and features fibroproliferative disease (e.g, scarring) due to inflammatory tissue destruction.

G) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchiectasis can manifest with shortness of breath, cough, crackles on lung exam, and, rarely, clubbing. However, the cough of chronic bronchiectasis is typically productive of copious amounts of sputum and sometimes blood, which is not seen in this patient. In addition, PFTs in patients with chronic bronchiectasis most commonly show a pattern of obstructive lung disease rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient. Lastly, this patient's CT scan lacks the classic findings of chronic bronchiectasis, which include dilated, air-filled bronchi with irregular bronchial wall thickening.

H) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) can also manifest with shortness of breath, clubbing, and cough. However, auscultation in patients with COPD typically reveals wheezing and reduced breath sounds rather than fine inspiratory crackles. In addition, this patient's PFTs are not typical of an obstructive lung disease. Moreover, imaging of the chest of patients with COPD often shows signs of hyperinflation and air trapping, not the findings seen in this patient.
questions.hint: A low FVC and high-normal FEV1/FVC ratio suggest a restrictive lung disease. Further expected findings would include a decreased DLCO.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of dyspnea and cough. He was diagnosed with esophageal cancer 10 months ago, for which he received radiochemotherapy. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Spirometry shows an FVC of 78% and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 95%. Which of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can manifest with dyspnea and cough and is associated with smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is often asymptomatic in the early stages of the disease, but patients may also present with dyspnea and cough. PAH affects the hydrostatic values of the pulmonary circulatory system and would not affect spirometry values.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis can manifest with cough and dyspnea and is associated with a history of smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema can manifest with cough and shortness of breath and is associated with a history of smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Allergic asthma can manifest with dyspnea and cough and is also associated with smoking and atopic dermatitis. It is characterized by acute exacerbations of symptoms and wheezing upon auscultation. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

F) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is the result of radiation-induced lung injury in patients who have received radiotherapy. In these cases, radiation pneumonitis occurs 4–12 weeks after the completion of radiation therapy. Pulmonary fibrosis usually develops > 6 months after radiation therapy due to the chronic inflammation and scarring of lung tissue. This leads to a pattern of restrictive lung disease, for which decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) on pulmonary function testing is a highly sensitive parameter.

G) INCORRECT:

This patient's history of smoking and malignancy are risk factors for pulmonary embolism, which can also manifest with dyspnea and cough. However, pulmonary embolism does not affect spirometry values, and both FEV1 and FEV1/FVC would remain normal.
questions.hint: Decreased lung volume (FVC of 78%) and a high/normal FEV1/FVC ratio (> 70%) on spirometry are consistent with restrictive lung disease. Here, the increase in peak expiratory flow rate when corrected for FVC (i.e., elevated FEV1/FVC ratio) is due to increased elastic recoil of the lung.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of a dry cough and shortness of breath on exertion. She also reports recurrent episodes of pain, stiffness, and swelling in her wrist and her left knee over the past 6 months. She had two miscarriages at age 24 and 28. Physical examination shows pallor, ulcerations on the palate, and annular hyperpigmented plaques on the arms and neck. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard over bilateral lower lung fields on auscultation. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial (A-a) gradient compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. The cause of a decreased A-a gradient is unknown. While the A-a gradient is normal in patients with hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when V/Q mismatch, shunting, and/or limited diffusion occur. The features of SLE seen here indicate that this patient is at increased risk for interstitial lung disease, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with clinical features that suggest SLE, as is the case here, are at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload cause right-sided filling pressures to increase. Therefore, an increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is likely to occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. However, interstitial lung disease manifests with a restrictive pattern of lung involvement. Therefore, airway resistance would be normal rather than increased.

D) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease results in collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli and obliteration of blood vessels, which interferes with the ability of the alveoli to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries. This group of disorders decreases the diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide (DLCO) and increases the A-a gradient.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung diseases such as emphysema are associated with increased lung compliance. The features of SLE seen here, however, suggest that this patient likely has restrictive lung disease. Restrictive lung diseases impair the ability of the lungs to expand, causing decreased rather than increased lung compliance.
questions.hint: In a middle-aged woman with a history of recurrent miscarriages, the features of anemia, oral ulcerations, joint pain, and annular (discoid) lesions in areas exposed to the sun raise suspicion for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), a connective tissue disorder. SLE is known to cause interstitial lung disease, which manifests with a dry cough, dyspnea, and fine basal inspiratory crackles.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive shortness of breath and an intermittent nonproductive cough over the past year. Initially, his breathlessness occurred only during exertion but over the past month, it has also occurred at rest. He was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 years ago but has not had any flares since then. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 95 kg (210 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/88 mm Hg. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. There is no swelling or deformity in the joints. Chest auscultation shows fine inspiratory crackles in both upper lung fields. Heart sounds are normal. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 81% and a vital capacity of 3.2 L (72% of predicted). A chest x-ray shows nodular interstitial opacifications measuring 5–25 mm in the upper lobes. A CT-guided needle aspiration biopsy of the largest nodule shows macrophages filled with black intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient most likely works in which of the following fields?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Construction workers (e.g., plumbing, roofing, insulation), firefighters wearing heat-resistant clothing, and shipbuilders with cumulative exposure to asbestos are at risk for asbestosis. While patients with asbestosis present with dyspnea and chronic cough, chest x-ray typically shows lower lobe involvement and pathognomonic findings of supradiaphragmatic and pleural calcifications. Diagnosis is aided by identification of the golden, beaded appearance of asbestos fibers in sputum, which are coated with iron and ferritin (thus called ferruginous bodies) after being phagocytosed by macrophages. Carbon-laden macrophages are not an expected biopsy finding in asbestosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Workers exposed to silica dust (e.g., in sandblasting, mining, casting metals) are at risk for silicosis, which usually manifests with a mixed obstructive-restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. Chest x-ray findings in silicosis also typically appear on the upper lobes more than the lower lobes with hilar eggshell calcifications and nodular opacities. However, lung biopsy findings typically show silicotic nodules, which are composed of collagen fibers surrounded by macrophages and lymphocytes, and, possibly, intra- or extracellular birefringent silica particles. Carbon-laden macrophages are not a common biopsy finding in silicosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Workers in uranium processing (especially mining) can be exposed to radon gas, a radioactive byproduct of uranium decay, which increases the risk of lung cancer. Chest x-ray findings in lung cancer typically show a solitary nodule, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, uranium workers can be exposed to dusts, including silica, which increases the risk for silicosis. In this condition, chest x-ray characteristically shows interstitial nodular opacities in the upper lobes similar to the findings in this patient. However, lung biopsy in silicosis typically shows silicotic nodules, which do not include carbon-laden macrophages.

D) INCORRECT:

Workers in aerospace manufacturing are often exposed to beryllium alloys, which can cause berylliosis following high-grade exposure. Although berylliosis can manifest with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests, lung biopsy typically reveals noncaseating granulomas similar to those seen in sarcoidosis rather than carbon-laden macrophages. Additionally, while opacities are also typically seen more in the upper lobes than the lower lobes of the lung, chest x-ray would reveal more of a reticular interstitial pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

Farmers are chronically exposed to organic dust (e.g., from molds, animal proteins) and are at risk for chronic hypersensitivity pneumonia, which is characterized by slowly progressive dyspnea, bilateral crackles, and a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests. However, chest x-ray typically shows ground-glass opacities with honeycombing (fibrotic changes), and lung biopsy is likely to reveal granulomatous inflammation with lymphocytes and polynuclear giant cells rather than carbon-laden macrophages.

F) CORRECT:

Coal miners are at increased risk of coal workers' pneumoconiosis, also called black lung disease, a more severe form of anthracosis caused by chronic occupational exposure to large amounts of carbon dust. Patients with coal workers' pneumoconiosis present with symptoms of chronic bronchitis, which can progress to severe dyspnea indicating massive pulmonary fibrosis. Inhaled carbon particles accumulate in alveolar macrophages and induce inflammation and fibrosis of the lung parenchyma. Chest x-ray can reveal small, nodular, potentially coalescing opacities in the upper lung lobes. Finally, lung biopsy characteristically shows deposition of dark pigment in macrophages, interstitial tissue, and hilar lymph nodes.

Caplan syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis, including coal workers' pneumoconiosis, that manifests with rheumatoid arthritis. Although this patient has a history of rheumatoid arthritis, he does not have Caplan syndrome. If he were to develop this complication, he would likely present with concurrent symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, more rapidly progressive shortness of breath, chest x-ray findings of more peripheral and/or larger nodules, and biopsy findings similar to those seen in rheumatoid nodules (i.e., central fibrinoid necrosis with histiocytes and surrounding epithelial cells).
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung biopsy specimen (H&E stain, low magnification)

Accumulations of carbon particles (anthracotic pigment) can be seen in the lung tissue. Some of the pigment can be found in pigment-laden macrophages. Also, collagenous fibrosis is predominant throughout the lung tissue.

This appearance is diagnostic of pneumoconiosis (e.g., coal workers' pneumoconiosis).
questions.hint: This patient's worsening dyspnea, cough, digital clubbing, bilateral inspiratory crackles, and restrictive pattern of lung disease on spirometry (normal to increased FEV1:FVC ratio, decreased VC) raises concern for interstitial lung disease. The biopsy findings, which indicate carbon-laden macrophages, and imaging findings are characteristic of exposure to a noxious agent in this field of work.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an 8-month history of persistent dry cough and shortness of breath with mild exertion. She reports feeling too weak to leave the house on most days. She has rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. She used to work as a hotel receptionist but quit her job a year ago because of worsening joint pain. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years but quit 2 years ago. Her medications include methotrexate, folic acid, and enalapril. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 148/82 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows an enlargement of the fingertips with increased curving of the nails and bilaterally enlarged metacarpophalangeal joints. Inspiratory crackles are heard over both lung bases. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown. The diffusing capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caplan syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome manifests with rapidly progressive exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. However, Caplan syndrome is caused by occupational exposure to asbestos, coal, or silica, of which this patient has no history. Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show basilar pulmonary nodules.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema is common in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which manifests with chronic cough, exertional dyspnea, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. This patient's smoking history increases her risk of developing emphysema. However, individuals with COPD usually don't show digital clubbing unless other comorbidities are present (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, lung cancer). Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show centrilobular emphysematous spaces with upper lobe predominance.
Image Description:

CT chest (high-resolution; axial plane) of a patient with panlobular emphysema

Reduced attenuation of the lung parenchyma is the result of abnormal enlargement of distal air spaces accompanied by destruction of secondary pulmonary lobules. Some narrowed thick-walled bronchi are also seen (examples indicated by white arrows).

The pattern of destruction in panlobular (panacinar) emphysema (green overlay) is diffuse within the secondary pulmonary lobule and the structures of the lobule are generally poorly seen on CT. In contrast, centrilobular (centriacinar) emphysema preserves visualization of much of the anatomy of the secondary lobule.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis can cause pleural effusion, which typically manifests with dyspnea and dry cough. However, pleural effusion also causes pleuritic chest pain and decreased or absent breath sounds on auscultation. Moreover, patients with pleural effusion do not present with digital clubbing and decreased DLCO. Finally, a CT scan of the chest would show peripheral, sickle-shaped attenuated areas between the lung parenchyma and the thoracic wall.
Image Description:

Chest CT with contrast (axial view; approx. at the level of T5)

Bilateral crescent-shaped attenuated areas (green overlay) are visible.

These findings are typical of pleural effusion.

AA = ascending aorta; DA = descending aorta; PT = pulmonary trunk, Vc = superior vena cava; PA = right pulmonary artery, V = vertebra

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, fatigue, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. However, pulmonary edema typically presents more acutely and a CT scan of the chest would show airspace consolidation and interlobular septal thickening (Kerley B lines). Moreover, digital clubbing is not expected in patients with pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) can occur in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis-associated lung disease and can manifest with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, nail clubbing, and decreased DLCO. However, patients with PH usually have chest pain on exertion and present with signs of right ventricle failure such as jugular vein distention, peripheral edema, a left parasternal heave. Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show a prominent right border, pronounced central pulmonary arteries, and vascular rarefaction in the peripheral lungs.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's chest CT scan findings are consistent with interstitial lung disease (ILD), which can manifest with persistent dry cough, exertional dyspnea, digital clubbing due to chronic hypoxia, and bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation. ILD is caused by excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung that leads to diffuse thickening of the alveolar walls and progressive fibrosis of the lung parenchyma, resulting in restrictive lung disease and decreased DLCO. While most cases of ILD are idiopathic (i.e., idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), this patient's ILD is most likely secondary to rheumatoid arthritis and/or methotrexate use. Smoking is also a risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest (with contrast; series 3: axial plane, mediastinal window; series 4: axial plane, lung window) of a patient with a history of work-related lignite and quartz dust exposure

There is evidence of chronic interstitial lung disease with extensive clustered cystic air space formation (honeycombing). Some areas show traction bronchiectasis. Enlarged reactive mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes are present. The main pulmonary artery is enlarged, which may indicate pulmonary hypertension. An indeterminate nodule is present in the right lung apex.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows multiple cystic lesions within the lung parenchyma (honeycomb pattern) and few areas of bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man is being followed for interstitial lung disease. Pulmonary function test results are consistent with restrictive lung disease, and he is found to have bibasilar honeycombing on CT of the chest. He reports slowly worsening dyspnea on exertion but says that he does not have fevers or worsening cough.
On physical examination, his vital signs are stable, with peripheral oxygen saturation of 95% on 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. He does not desaturate with ambulation. Bilateral inspiratory crackles are noted at the lung bases.
Which one of the following therapeutic options is most likely to improve this patient’s quality of life?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although it is important to ensure that patients with IPF receive adequate supplemental oxygen, this patient does not desaturate below 92% at rest or with ambulation.

B) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) were previously used often to treat IPF, but their lack of benefit for this condition has become clear in the past decade. Similar results have been found for other immunomodulating drugs.

C) CORRECT:

Exercise limitation profoundly affects the quality of life of patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). A multidisciplinary approach to pulmonary rehabilitation has been shown to improve quality-of-life scores in small trials.

Glucocorticoids (e.g., prednisone) were previously used often to treat IPF, but their lack of benefit for this condition has become clear in the past decade. Similar results have been found for other immunomodulating drugs. Two newer agents, nintedanib and pirfenidone, have been shown to slow progression of disease, but they do not confer a mortality benefit and have limited effect on symptoms. In addition, both have challenging adverse-effect profiles that often limit their use.

Although it is important to ensure that patients with IPF receive adequate supplemental oxygen, this patient does not desaturate below 92% at rest or with ambulation.

Key learning point: The best therapeutic strategy for treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is supportive therapy, including pulmonary rehabilitation and adequate oxygen supplementation.

D) INCORRECT:

Compared with placebo, treatment with azathioprine, prednisone, and N-acetylcysteine has been associated with greater morbidity and mortality.

E) INCORRECT:

Lung transplantation can be an option for patients with IPF, but the benefit is greatest in younger patients. Although advanced age is only a relative contraindication to transplantation, this patient’s age makes it unlikely that he will be a candidate.

questions.text:
An otherwise healthy 65-year-old woman presents with persistent shortness of breath and cough. She reports that during the past 6 months, she has had recurrent bouts of pneumonia, confirmed by migrating opacities on chest radiograph, that have been treated with multiple courses of oral antibiotics. She has had intermittent fever and cough, but she states that she has had no sick contacts, sputum production, or hemoptysis. She has never smoked tobacco, and a thorough exposure history is unrevealing.
A CT scan visualizes areas of consolidation. Surgical lung biopsy shows no evidence of infection or malignancy but reveals patchy alveolar filling with loose plugs of granulation tissue.
Which one of the following is an appropriate initial therapeutic option for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antifungals, such as fluconazole, are ineffective for cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

B) INCORRECT:

Because cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is caused by inflammation in the alveoli and not by an infection, antibiotics such as levofloxacin are not likely to be effective.

C) INCORRECT:

Some patients with cryptogenic organizing pneumonia may relapse after initial response to the glucocorticoid, at which point an alternative immunosuppressive therapy, such as azathioprine, may be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Because cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is caused by inflammation in the alveoli and not by an infection, antibiotics such as piperacillin-tazobactam are not likely to be effective.

E) CORRECT:

Patients who have cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP) often present with flu-like illness, cough, and dyspnea. Radiographic findings are nonspecific and include patchy bilateral alveolar filling processes. COP is often treated unsuccessfully with antibiotic courses before further evaluation reveals organizing pneumonia (i.e., not related to an infection). The histopathologic pattern of organizing pneumonia is characterized by patchy filling of alveoli and respiratory bronchioles with loose plugs of granulation tissue. Most patients with COP respond to a glucocorticoid, such as prednisone.

Key learning point: Optimal first-line therapy for cryptogenic organizing pneumonia is glucocorticoid therapy.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit with a 2-day history of fevers and increased dyspnea on exertion. He was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis by biopsy 2 years ago and has been managed with 2 liters of supplemental oxygen. He has no other medical problems.
His blood pressure is 128/74 mm Hg, his heart rate is 120 beats per minute, and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. He now requires 4 liters of supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 92%. He has bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Cardiac examination is notable only for tachycardia; there is no pedal edema. The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
His leukocyte count is 6800 per mm3 (reference range, 4500–11,000).
A chest radiograph and CT of the chest are obtained (figures 1 and 2).
In addition to initiating empiric antibiotic therapy, which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's imaging reveals chronic interstitial changes with diffuse ground-glass opacities in the pulmonary parenchyma. The differential for ground-glass opacities includes acute exacerbation of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), infectious pneumonia, pulmonary edema, and pulmonary hemorrhage.

After initiating empiric antibiotic coverage of organisms that cause community-acquired pneumonia, the next step is to perform bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. This procedure enhances diagnostic accuracy for underlying infection, guides antimicrobial therapy, and allows for cell counts and differential, which helps reveal pulmonary hemorrhage, eosinophilic pneumonia, and hypersensitivity pneumonitis.

Key learning point: Worsening hypoxemia in a patient with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis may represent an acute exacerbation of the IPF, but other diagnoses must be ruled out.

B) INCORRECT:

Pirfenidone has been shown to confer modest benefit in chronic treatment of IPF; in contrast, N-acetylcysteine was not superior to placebo in a study of patients with chronic IPF. Neither of these drugs is known to be beneficial for treatment of acute exacerbations. Current guidelines give a weak recommendation for treating acute exacerbations with glucocorticoids. If a clinician chooses to treat with glucocorticoids, then these medications should not be started until infection has been eliminated as a cause of the new symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Video-assisted thoracoscopic lung biopsy is often required to make a diagnosis in patients with acute respiratory failure with unclear etiology and interstitial fibrosis, but it is unlikely to be helpful in a patient whose diagnosis has already been confirmed.

D) INCORRECT:

Pirfenidone has been shown to confer modest benefit in chronic treatment of IPF; in contrast, N-acetylcysteine was not superior to placebo in a study of patients with chronic IPF. Neither of these drugs is known to be beneficial for treatment of acute exacerbations. Current guidelines give a weak recommendation for treating acute exacerbations with glucocorticoids. If a clinician chooses to treat with glucocorticoids, then these medications should not be started until infection has been eliminated as a cause of the new symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Adding an antifungal agent would be inappropriate unless bronchoscopic specimens confirmed fungal disease.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is referred for evaluation of chronic cough and progressively worsening shortness of breath during the past 3 months. He has a history of Hodgkin lymphoma and underwent chemotherapy 2 years ago with doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine. His symptoms improved with prednisone but have not resolved completely. Tapering the prednisone dose resulted in worsening symptoms. The patient’s oxygen saturation is 93% while he is breathing ambient air at rest, but it falls to 82% on ambulation.
A representative CT image from the patient was performed before his current visit (figure).
Which one of the following agents is most likely to have caused this patient’s respiratory symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxorubicin, vinblastine, dacarbazine, and prednisone are not routinely associated with pulmonary toxicity.

B) INCORRECT:

Doxorubicin, vinblastine, dacarbazine, and prednisone are not routinely associated with pulmonary toxicity.

C) INCORRECT:

Doxorubicin, vinblastine, dacarbazine, and prednisone are not routinely associated with pulmonary toxicity.

D) CORRECT:

Although Hodgkin lymphoma often responds to chemotherapy, the first-line treatment regimen, known as ABVD (adriamycin, bleomycin, vinblastine, dacarbazine), carries substantial risk for bleomycin pulmonary toxicity (BPT). BPT has been well described in patients with Hodgkin lymphoma who are treated with bleomycin-containing regimens. The measured risk for BPT after ABVD exposure varies in the literature; it was about 18% in one observational study.

Patients with BPT present, months to years after their ABVD exposure, with bilateral interstitial opacities on chest radiograph or CT, symptoms of shortness of breath or chronic cough, and no evidence of an infectious etiology. Patients older than 40 are at increased risk for BPT after ABVD use. Five-year survival rates are lower among ABVD-treated patients who develop BPT than among those who do not develop BPT. No standard treatment for BPT exists, but glucocorticoid therapy coupled with cessation of bleomycin exposure is the most common approach.

Key learning point: The most likely agent to cause dyspnea, chronic cough, and bilateral interstitial lung opacities on imaging in a patient being treated for Hodgkin lymphoma is bleomycin.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxorubicin, vinblastine, dacarbazine, and prednisone are not routinely associated with pulmonary toxicity.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old man presents with a one-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and dry cough. He has no history of fevers, chills, weight loss, joint swelling, morning stiffness, dysphagia, heartburn, or rashes.
He is a retired executive. He does not have birds or use humidifiers, and his house of 40 years has never had water damage. He has never smoked cigarettes.
On examination, he is afebrile, with a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 89% while he is breathing ambient air at rest, and it drops to 86% after a short walk. He has bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination does not reveal any murmurs or gallops. The patient has no peripheral edema. A joint examination is normal, and there are no skin changes.
Pulmonary function test results show a reduced total lung capacity and a normal FEV1 /FVC ratio.
Testing is negative for antinuclear antibodies, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, rheumatoid factor, and antitopoisomerase antibody.
CT of the chest is performed (figure).
What is the best next step in this patient’s care?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The combination of prednisone, azathioprine, and N-acetylcysteine should not be used for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, because it has been shown to cause harm.

B) INCORRECT:

The use of cyclophosphamide and other immunosuppressants has shown no benefit in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s high-resolution CT of the chest shows extensive pulmonary fibrosis or scarring and honeycombing. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis typically manifests with progressive dyspnea and a nonproductive cough. Most patients will eventually become hypoxemic. Hypoxemia (defined as a partial pressure of oxygen ≤55 mm Hg or oxygen saturation ≤88%) at rest or with exertion should be treated with supplemental oxygen to delay the development of pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.

Both pirfenidone (an antifibrotic agent) and nintedanib (a tyrosine kinase receptor blocker) have been approved for treatment of IPF based on their ability to slow progression of disease; however, neither has been shown to have an effect on mortality, and both have challenging adverse-effect profiles. Nintedanib commonly causes diarrhea and liver function test abnormalities, while nausea and rash can limit tolerance of pirfenidone.

Key learning point: The best initial treatment in a hypoxemic patient with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is oxygen.

D) INCORRECT:

Lung transplantation is the only intervention that improves the survival of patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, but it is not the first intervention that should be pursued. In addition, the majority of transplant centers do not perform transplantation in patients older than age 70.

E) INCORRECT:

A patient with these symptoms can be diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis on the basis of a classic radiographic pattern if all other potential causes (such as connective tissue disease or hypersensitivity pneumonitis) have been ruled out. In this setting, open-lung biopsy is not required.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman reports 9 months of a dry cough and progressive dyspnea that is exacerbated by exertion. She can no longer climb the stairs in her home without severe symptoms. She quit smoking more than 10 years ago. She is thin and otherwise healthy.
The patient requires 5 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation of >90%. She has diffuse crackles in both lungs, most prominent at the bases. Her fingers are clubbed. She has normal jugular venous pressure, no evidence of peripheral edema, and no rashes or skin lesions.
High-resolution CT of the chest is obtained (figure). Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody tests are negative.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is most often found in patients with a history of asthma. Patients present with recurrent bouts of fever and bronchial obstruction with expectoration of brownish mucus. Patients can have a peripheral eosinophilia. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is not associated with clubbing. Chest imaging often reveals central bronchiectasis with mucous plugging.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare disease that results from smooth-muscle growth in the lungs and leads to cyst formation. It is found in women of childbearing age and often in patients with tuberous sclerosis. CT reveals diffuse, thin-walled cysts.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia frequently manifests with symptoms similar to those of a lower respiratory tract infection, with cough, dyspnea, fever, and malaise; however, symptoms and opacities on chest radiographs do not resolve despite appropriate antibiotic therapies. Imaging reveals patchy air-space consolidation with ground-glass or nodular consolidations. Fibrotic changes are not common with cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

D) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis, is a progressive fibrotic lung disease that typically has an insidious onset of dyspnea, a poor prognosis, and few treatment options. Clinical examination demonstrates bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate a restrictive pattern with reduced gas exchange.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by the histopathologic pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia. On imaging, usual interstitial pneumonia is characterized by peripheral honeycombing (subpleural stacked cysts, as identified in the figure with blue arrows), traction bronchiectasis (red arrow), and a basilar and subpleural predominance. Connective-tissue diseases often manifest as fibrotic changes in the lung, but this patient has no symptoms or laboratory findings consistent with an autoimmune diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Langerhans-cell histiocytosis manifests with symptoms similar to those of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis but has a classic radiographic appearance of thin-walled cysts and small nodules that predominantly involve the mid and upper zones (in contrast to lower zone involvement in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). It is most often seen in younger patients aged 20 to 40 and is associated with current cigarette smoking.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents for evaluation of progressive dyspnea on exertion and dry cough that she has been experiencing for 9 months. She has no associated fevers, chills, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, or peripheral edema. However, she reports having mild pain in the joints of her hands in the morning. She has no notable medical history and takes no medications.
Vital signs are normal, and the patient is in no distress. Physical examination reveals bilateral basilar, dry inspiratory crackles and mild swelling in the metacarpophalangeal joints, without associated tenderness to palpation, but is otherwise unremarkable.
A chest radiograph reveals diffuse abnormalities; a high-resolution CT scan, obtained for follow-up comparison, is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to help guide further treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Anti-citrullinated peptide antibody (ACPA) is quite specific for rheumatoid arthritis and is often measured in conjunction with rheumatoid factor. A positive ACPA would be most likely to establish a specific etiology of newly diagnosed interstitial lung disease and to suggest a specific treatment strategy. It is not uncommon for the pulmonary manifestations of rheumatoid arthritis at the time of diagnosis to be more pronounced than the arthritis symptoms, as in this patient. In this case, the CT scan reveals honeycomb, subpleural fibrosis consistent with interstitial lung disease associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

Key learning point: A patient with suspected interstitial lung disease and symptoms of arthritis should undergo diagnostic testing for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide antibody.

B) INCORRECT:

An elevated serum angiotensin-converting-enzyme level may suggest sarcoidosis, but it is very nonspecific and would not be diagnostically helpful or identify a specific treatment strategy.

C) INCORRECT:

Although scleroderma can be associated with interstitial lung disease, this patient’s history of metacarpophalangeal pain and swelling is more consistent with rheumatoid arthritis; therefore, anti-scleroderma-70 antibody testing is not the most appropriate choice.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation is not typical for pulmonary alveolar proteinosis, and the high-resolution CT does not show the characteristic “crazy paving” pattern that is typical of this disease; therefore, a granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor antibody test is unlikely to be positive.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient’s erythrocyte sedimentation rate is likely to be elevated, an erythrocyte sedimentation rate is not specific for an underlying disease.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with dyspnea that started a few months ago and has worsened. She can no longer walk more than two blocks without becoming short of breath. For the past year, she has noted changes in her skin, starting in her hands but progressing to her legs, chest, and face. She feels her skin is tightening, and she reports difficulty opening and closing her hands and mouth. She also says that her fingers lose their color in cold weather.
The patient’s physical examination reveals a BMI of 25, a blood pressure of 108/92 mm Hg, a heart rate of 92 beats per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% while she is breathing ambient air, but it drops to 84% when she walks to the bathroom. Her skin is markedly thickened and tethered from her fingertips to her wrists and moderately thickened proximally to the elbows and around her mouth, with a mildly reduced oral aperture.
Her cardiac examination is normal, but her lung examination reveals faint rales heard throughout both lung fields. She has no evidence of lower-extremity edema. A portable chest radiograph is unremarkable, and an electrocardiogram is normal.
Laboratory testing documents an antinuclear antibody titer of 1:10,240, nucleolar pattern. Other blood tests include a normal D-dimer level and negative tests for anti-double-stranded DNA and anti-Smith antibodies, but a positive test for anti-Scl-70 antibodies.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the cause of this patient’s shortness of breath?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism are each reasonable choices for a patient with new-onset dyspnea, but a patient with chronic shortness of breath and diffuse systemic scleroderma is more likely to have interstitial lung disease. The lung images achieved with CT pulmonary angiography are inferior to those achieved with a high-resolution CT directed to the lung parenchyma.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis are at high risk for interstitial lung disease, particularly those with anti-Scl-70 antibodies. High-resolution CT of the chest is more sensitive than a chest radiograph for detecting early changes of interstitial lung disease. High-resolution CT of the chest is appropriate for patients with diffuse systemic sclerosis at the time of scleroderma diagnosis, as well as for patients who have new symptoms of dyspnea or worsening lung volume measurements on pulmonary function testing.

Key learning point: The pulmonary process that frequently leads to dyspnea in a patient with diffuse systemic sclerosis is interstitial lung disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Right heart catheterization is the study of choice to confirm the presence of pulmonary hypertension. Pulmonary hypertension is more commonly a complication of limited, rather than diffuse, systemic sclerosis and is therefore less likely than interstitial lung disease in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Transesophageal echocardiography is the most appropriate study to assess for valvular vegetations in patients with suspected endocarditis.

E) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan or CT pulmonary angiography to evaluate for pulmonary embolism are each reasonable choices for a patient with new-onset dyspnea, but a patient with chronic shortness of breath and diffuse systemic scleroderma is more likely to have interstitial lung disease. The lung images achieved with CT pulmonary angiography are inferior to those achieved with a high-resolution CT directed to the lung parenchyma.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old man with a history of obesity, coronary artery disease, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, obstructive sleep apnea, type 2 diabetes, and depression reports 4 months of progressive dyspnea and nonproductive cough. He has been evaluated twice at an urgent care center and received glucocorticoids and antibiotics without improvement in his symptoms. He has had no fevers, chills, sweats, nausea, vomiting, reflux, hemoptysis, chest pain, or lower-extremity swelling. He lives a sedentary life as a retired banker and had no relevant occupational exposures. He has a 50-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit 5 years ago.
On examination, he has a temperature of 36.9°C, a heart rate of 70 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 160/92 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a resting oxygen saturation of 93% while he breathes ambient air, and a BMI of 32. Cardiac examination reveals a regular rate and rhythm without murmur. He has bibasilar crackles on lung auscultation and clubbing on his hands. No jugular venous distention is present, and there is no lower-extremity swelling.
Notable laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
15.8
13.5–17.5


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
8800
4500–11,000


Creatinine (mg/dL)
1.8
0.8–1.3

<0.5
<0.5

0.01
0–0.03

53
≤62


An electrocardiogram shows evidence of prior infarct but no acute changes. A chest radiograph shows slightly reduced lung volumes without obvious opacities.
Pulmonary function testing shows the following results:



Patient value
