What is the most appropriate next diagnostic test for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT pulmonary angiography is a good test to evaluate for acute pulmonary embolism (PE). However, this patient’s history is not consistent with a PE (no pleuritic chest pain, tachycardia, diminished mobility, or unilateral lower-extremity swelling), and he would be at low risk for PE according to Wells criteria. In addition, the patient has evidence of renal impairment, and the use of contrast dye should be avoided at least until he has received adequate hydration.

B) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan would be the test of choice to look for chronic thromboembolic disease, which is a common cause of pulmonary hypertension, but there is no evidence of volume overload in this case, and the first step in assessing for pulmonary hypertension would be echocardiography.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s clinical presentation — including progressive shortness of breath, crackles on lung examination, and clubbing — is classic for interstitial lung disease (ILD). The findings on pulmonary function testing are also consistent with this diagnosis, showing moderate restriction (total lung capacity between 60% and 80% of predicted), a moderate reduction in diffusion capacity, and no evidence of obstruction. In a patient with dyspnea whose pulmonary function tests show restriction with a reduction in diffusion capacity, the most appropriate next step is to obtain a high-resolution chest CT to evaluate for a cause of these findings, including ILD such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Key learning point: High-resolution chest CT should be obtained for patients with chronic dyspnea and restriction on pulmonary function testing to evaluate for interstitial lung disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing is important to consider in patients whose dyspnea remains unexplained despite a thorough workup. If this patient’s further tests return normal, then cardiopulmonary exercise testing would be reasonable to consider.

E) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography is useful to look for evidence of right or left ventricular dysfunction but is not indicated at this time, as the patient has no evidence of volume overload or new cardiac dysfunction. If this patient's diagnosis is confirmed with further testing, then an echocardiogram to assess right ventricular function and pulmonary artery pressures might be a reasonable next step.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman reports 9 months of a dry cough and progressive dyspnea that is exacerbated by exertion. She can no longer climb the stairs in her home without severe symptoms. She quit smoking more than 10 years ago. She is otherwise healthy. The patient requires 5 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation of >90%. She has diffuse crackles in both lungs, most prominent at the bases. Her fingers are clubbed. High-resolution CT of the chest is obtained (figure). Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody tests are negative. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is most often found in patients with a history of asthma. Patients present with recurrent bouts of fever and bronchial obstruction with expectoration of brownish mucus. Patients can have a peripheral eosinophilia. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is not associated with clubbing. Chest imaging often reveals central bronchiectasis with mucous plugging.

B) INCORRECT:

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare disease that results from smooth-muscle growth in the lungs and leads to cyst formation. It is found in women of childbearing age and often in patients with tuberous sclerosis. CT reveals diffuse, thin-walled cysts.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia frequently manifests with symptoms similar to those of a lower respiratory tract infection, with cough, dyspnea, fever, and malaise; however, symptoms and opacities on chest radiographs do not resolve despite appropriate antibiotic therapies. Imaging reveals patchy air-space consolidation with ground-glass or nodular consolidations. Fibrotic changes are not common with cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

D) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis, is a progressive fibrotic lung disease that typically has an insidious onset of dyspnea, a poor prognosis, and few treatment options. Clinical examination demonstrates bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate a restrictive pattern with reduced gas exchange.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by the histopathologic pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia. On imaging, usual interstitial pneumonia is characterized by peripheral honeycombing (subpleural stacked cysts, as identified in the figure with blue arrows), traction bronchiectasis (red arrow), and a basilar and subpleural predominance. Connective-tissue diseases often manifest as fibrotic changes in the lung, but this patient has no symptoms or laboratory findings consistent with an autoimmune diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Langerhans-cell histiocytosis manifests with symptoms similar to those of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis but has a classic radiographic appearance of thin-walled cysts and small nodules that predominantly involve the mid and upper zones (in contrast to lower zone involvement in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). It is most often seen in younger patients aged 20 to 40 and is associated with current cigarette smoking.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the office for worsening fatigue and dyspnea for several months. She has not been seen by a healthcare professional in 10 years. She is also concerned about the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for the patient's nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.
Image Description:

Fingers (A) and thumb (B) of the right hand of a 22-year-old female patient presenting with weakness, weight loss, and reduced appetite

The nails are centrally concave and bend upwards distally, resulting in a characteristic spoon shape.

The most common cause of koilonychia is iron deficiency anemia, as was the case here.

C) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

E) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the office because of a 6-month history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Cardiopulmonary examination shows fine inspiratory crackles bilaterally. There is clubbing present in the fingers bilaterally. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) show an FVC of 78% of expected and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can also manifest with shortness of breath, cough, and crackles on lung exam. However, clubbing is not a typical feature, and this patient does not have other symptoms of sarcoidosis (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss) or any extrapulmonary findings of the disease (e.g., arthritis, anterior uveitis, erythema nodosum). In addition, while sarcoidosis can, in rare cases, manifest with a similar PFT pattern, normal findings are more common. Lastly, chest imaging in sarcoidosis is more likely to show extensive bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is not seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given his PFTs, imaging results, shortness of breath, persistent nonproductive cough, and bilateral fine inspiratory crackles, and clubbing (which suggests chronic hypoxia). PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis most commonly show a pattern typical of restrictive lung disease, and the honeycombing seen on this patient's CT scan is also consistent with this diagnosis. Pulmonary fibrosis is most commonly idiopathic but can also be associated with certain risk factors, such as medication use (e.g., methotrexate, bleomycin, amiodarone), connective tissue disease (e.g., scleroderma), and environmental exposures (e.g., silicosis, coal dust exposure).

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis can occur in various forms, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, and invasive aspergillosis. Aspergillosis is rare, and this patient does not have any reported risk factors associated with aspergillosis (e.g., immunosuppression, preexisting lung disease), which makes this diagnosis very unlikely. In addition, PFTs in patients with ABPA typically show signs of obstructive lung disease, rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may develop pulmonary hypertension as a result of his underlying condition, pulmonary hypertension alone would not cause this patient's symptoms, clinical findings, PFT abnormalities, and imaging study results.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchiectasis can manifest with shortness of breath, cough, crackles on lung exam, and, rarely, clubbing. However, the cough of chronic bronchiectasis is typically productive of copious amounts of sputum and sometimes blood, which is not seen in this patient. In addition, PFTs in patients with chronic bronchiectasis most commonly show a pattern of obstructive lung disease rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient. Lastly, this patient's CT scan lacks the classic findings of chronic bronchiectasis, which include dilated, air-filled bronchi with irregular bronchial wall thickening.
questions.hint: A low FVC and high-normal FEV1/FVC ratio suggest a restrictive lung disease. Further expected findings would include a decreased DLCO.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the office because of an 8-month history of persistent dry cough and shortness of breath with mild exertion. She has rheumatoid arthritis and hypertension. She works as a hotel receptionist. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 27 years but quit 2 years ago. Her medications include methotrexate, folic acid, and enalapril. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Physical examination shows an enlargement of the fingertips with increased curving of the nails and bilaterally enlarged metacarpophalangeal joints. Inspiratory crackles are heard over both lung bases. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest is shown. The diffusing capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Caplan syndrome is a rare complication of pneumoconiosis in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Caplan syndrome manifests with rapidly progressive exertional dyspnea, cough, fatigue, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. However, Caplan syndrome is caused by occupational exposure to asbestos, coal, or silica, of which this patient has no history. Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show basilar pulmonary nodules.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema is common in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which manifests with chronic cough, exertional dyspnea, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. This patient's smoking history increases her risk of developing emphysema. However, individuals with COPD usually don't show digital clubbing unless other comorbidities are present (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, lung cancer). Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show centrilobular emphysematous spaces with upper lobe predominance.
Image Description:

CT chest (high-resolution; axial plane) of a patient with panlobular emphysema

Reduced attenuation of the lung parenchyma is the result of abnormal enlargement of distal air spaces accompanied by destruction of secondary pulmonary lobules. Some narrowed thick-walled bronchi are also seen (examples indicated by white arrows).

The pattern of destruction in panlobular (panacinar) emphysema (green overlay) is diffuse within the secondary pulmonary lobule and the structures of the lobule are generally poorly seen on CT. In contrast, centrilobular (centriacinar) emphysema preserves visualization of much of the anatomy of the secondary lobule.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, fatigue, crackles on chest auscultation, and decreased DLCO. However, pulmonary edema typically presents more acutely and a CT scan of the chest would show airspace consolidation and interlobular septal thickening (Kerley B lines). Moreover, digital clubbing is not expected in patients with pulmonary edema.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) can occur in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis-associated lung disease and can manifest with exertional dyspnea, fatigue, nail clubbing, and decreased DLCO. However, patients with PH usually have chest pain on exertion and present with signs of right ventricle failure such as jugular vein distention, peripheral edema, a left parasternal heave. Moreover, a CT scan of the chest would show a prominent right border, pronounced central pulmonary arteries, and vascular rarefaction in the peripheral lungs.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's chest CT scan findings are consistent with interstitial lung disease (ILD), which can manifest with persistent dry cough, exertional dyspnea, digital clubbing due to chronic hypoxia, and bibasilar inspiratory crackles on auscultation. ILD is caused by excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung that leads to diffuse thickening of the alveolar walls and progressive fibrosis of the lung parenchyma, resulting in restrictive lung disease and decreased DLCO. While most cases of ILD are idiopathic (i.e., idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), this patient's ILD is most likely secondary to rheumatoid arthritis and/or methotrexate use. Smoking is also a risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT chest (with contrast; series 3: axial plane, mediastinal window; series 4: axial plane, lung window) of a patient with a history of work-related lignite and quartz dust exposure

There is evidence of chronic interstitial lung disease with extensive clustered cystic air space formation (honeycombing). Some areas show traction bronchiectasis. Enlarged reactive mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes are present. The main pulmonary artery is enlarged, which may indicate pulmonary hypertension. An indeterminate nodule is present in the right lung apex.
questions.hint: The CT scan shows multiple cystic lesions within the lung parenchyma (honeycomb pattern) and few areas of bronchiectasis.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive exertional dyspnea and a nonproductive cough. He denies environmental or occupational exposures and has no history of smoking. Physical examination reveals bibasilar inspiratory crackles and a normal cardiac exam. Laboratory investigations, including serum autoantibodies, are unremarkable (see reports).

Oxygen saturation
94% on room air


Pulmonary function tests: Restrictive pattern
Chest X-ray: Diffuse reticular opacities

Which of the following investigations is the most appropriate next step to further characterize his lung pathology?

choices.text: High-resolution CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) lung biopsy provides definitive histopathologic evidence but is invasive and reserved for cases where noninvasive imaging is inconclusive. The patient's diffuse reticular opacities and restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests suggest interstitial lung disease, which can be characterized by high-resolution CT before considering invasive procedures.

B) CORRECT:

High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest is crucial for evaluating suspected interstitial lung disease. It provides detailed images that can identify specific patterns such as ground-glass opacities, reticulations, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. In this patient with progressive dyspnea, nonproductive cough, bibasilar inspiratory crackles, and diffuse reticular opacities on chest X-ray, HRCT helps confirm the diagnosis and subtype the interstitial lung disease, guiding appropriate management. HRCT is more sensitive than plain radiography and less invasive than surgical lung biopsy, making it the preferred next step.

Key learning point: In the evaluation of interstitial lung disease, a high-resolution CT scan of the chest is the most valuable diagnostic tool as it provides detailed images of the lung parenchyma and helps identify specific patterns associated with different types of ILD.
Image Description:

CT chest (lung window; a: axial plane; b: coronal plane) of a patient with progressive dyspnea on exertion

Extensive reticular interstitial thickening with honeycombing (examples indicated by green outlines) is accompanied by traction bronchiectasis (examples indicated by red arrows). The distribution is subpleural and basal predominant. The appearance is diagnostic of a usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. There are no CT features to suggest an alternative diagnosis.

DA: descending aorta; H: heart

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is useful for assessing cellular profiles in certain interstitial lung diseases, such as hypersensitivity pneumonitis or infections. However, this patient lacks environmental exposures and has unremarkable serum autoantibodies, suggesting a fibrotic rather than inflammatory process. BAL does not provide the architectural detail needed to differentiate fibrotic interstitial lung diseases, which is better achieved with high-resolution CT.

D) INCORRECT:

Transthoracic echocardiography evaluates cardiac structure and function, useful in suspected cardiac causes of dyspnea. This patient’s normal cardiac exam and imaging findings suggest a primary pulmonary process, reducing the likelihood of significant cardiac pathology. Echocardiography is not indicated for further characterizing lung findings in this context.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of worsening shortness of breath on exertion and dry cough. He also reports fatigue and difficulty swallowing solid foods. He notes that his fingers often turn blue and become painful in cold weather. He occasionally smokes cigarettes on weekends. His temperature is 37°C, pulse is 87/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 126/85 mm Hg. On examination, the skin over his trunk and arms is thickened and tightened. Fine inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally over the lower lung fields. Which one of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) is caused by collagen deposition in the walls of alveoli, which interferes with their ability to exchange gases with pulmonary capillaries, resulting in decreased carbon monoxide diffusing capacity of the lungs (DLCO). Manifestations of ILD include progressive exertional dyspnea, chronic nonproductive cough, and inspiratory crackles on auscultation.

Pulmonary involvement (e.g., ILD, pulmonary arterial hypertension, lung cancer) is the leading cause of death in patients with diffuse SSc.

Key learning point: Diffuse systemic sclerosis commonly causes interstitial lung disease, leading to decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) due to collagen deposition in the alveolar walls.

B) INCORRECT:

Airway resistance, which is the resistance of the pulmonary tree to airflow during inspiration and expiration, is a parameter for airway obstruction and is typically increased in obstructive lung disease. As SSc causes restrictive lung disease, airway resistance is not affected.

C) INCORRECT:

The alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) compares the oxygenation status of alveoli and arterial blood. While the A-a gradient is normal in cases of hypoventilation and low levels of inspired oxygen, it becomes elevated when ventilation-perfusion mismatch, shunting, and limited diffusion occur. This patient with signs and symptoms of diffuse SSc is at risk of pulmonary fibrosis, which manifests with an increased A-a gradient.

D) INCORRECT:

Restrictive lung diseases increase the elastic recoil of lungs and impair their ability to expand, thus causing decreased lung compliance. This patient with diffuse SSc likely has restrictive lung disease and, therefore, decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient with diffuse SSc is at risk of developing pulmonary hypertension. Right-sided filling pressures increase as a result of pulmonary hypertension and an increase in right ventricular afterload. An increase rather than decrease in right atrial pressure is thus likely to ensue.
questions.hint: The combination of pulmonary symptoms, dysphagia, Raynaud phenomenon, and sclerotic skin raises concern for diffuse systemic sclerosis (SSc), which frequently causes interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of dyspnea and cough. He was diagnosed with esophageal cancer 10 months ago and received radiochemotherapy. He has a history of atopic dermatitis and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. On lung auscultation, breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Spirometry shows an FVC of 78% and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 95%. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis can manifest with dyspnea and cough and is associated with smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is the result of radiation-induced lung injury in patients who have received radiotherapy. In these cases, radiation pneumonitis occurs 4–12 weeks after the completion of radiation therapy. Pulmonary fibrosis usually develops > 6 months after radiation therapy due to the chronic inflammation and scarring of lung tissue. This leads to a pattern of restrictive lung disease, for which decreased diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide (DLCO) on pulmonary function testing is a highly sensitive parameter.

Key learning point: Radiation-induced pulmonary fibrosis presents as a restrictive lung disease with decreased lung volumes and typically develops more than six months after radiotherapy due to chronic inflammation and scarring.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary emphysema can manifest with cough and shortness of breath and is associated with a history of smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergic asthma can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and is also associated with smoking and atopic dermatitis. It is characterized by acute exacerbations of symptoms and wheezing upon auscultation. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis can manifest with cough and dyspnea and is associated with a history of smoking. However, pulmonary function testing would reveal a pattern of obstructive lung disease (FEV1/FVC < 70%), unlike the pattern of restrictive lung disease seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Decreased lung volume (FVC of 78%) and a high/normal FEV1/FVC ratio (> 70%) on spirometry are consistent with restrictive lung disease. Here, the increase in peak expiratory flow rate when corrected for FVC (i.e., elevated FEV1/FVC ratio) is due to increased elastic recoil of the lung.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 9-month history of dry cough and progressive dyspnea that worsens with exertion. She is now unable to climb the stairs in her home without experiencing severe symptoms. She quit smoking more than 10 years ago. She requires 5 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula to maintain an oxygen saturation above 90%. On examination, she has diffuse crackles in both lungs, most prominent at the bases, and clubbing of the fingers. High-resolution CT of the chest is obtained (figure). Rheumatoid factor and antinuclear antibody tests are negative. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, the most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis, is a progressive fibrotic lung disease that typically has an insidious onset of dyspnea, a poor prognosis, and few treatment options. Clinical examination demonstrates bibasilar inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function tests demonstrate a restrictive pattern with reduced gas exchange.

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is characterized by the histopathologic pattern of usual interstitial pneumonia. On imaging, usual interstitial pneumonia is characterized by peripheral honeycombing (subpleural stacked cysts, as identified in the figure with blue arrows), traction bronchiectasis (red arrow), and a basilar and subpleural predominance. Connective-tissue diseases often manifest as fibrotic changes in the lung, but this patient has no symptoms or laboratory findings consistent with an autoimmune diagnosis.

Key learning point: The most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonitis is idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is most often found in patients with a history of asthma. Patients present with recurrent bouts of fever and bronchial obstruction with expectoration of brownish mucus. Patients can have a peripheral eosinophilia. Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is not associated with clubbing. Chest imaging often reveals central bronchiectasis with mucous plugging.

C) INCORRECT:

Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia frequently manifests with symptoms similar to those of a lower respiratory tract infection, with cough, dyspnea, fever, and malaise; however, symptoms and opacities on chest radiographs do not resolve despite appropriate antibiotic therapies. Imaging reveals patchy air-space consolidation with ground-glass or nodular consolidations. Fibrotic changes are not common with cryptogenic organizing pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare disease that results from smooth-muscle growth in the lungs and leads to cyst formation. It is found in women of childbearing age and often in patients with tuberous sclerosis. CT reveals diffuse, thin-walled cysts.

E) INCORRECT:

Langerhans-cell histiocytosis manifests with symptoms similar to those of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis but has a classic radiographic appearance of thin-walled cysts and small nodules that predominantly involve the mid and upper zones (in contrast to lower zone involvement in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis). It is most often seen in younger patients aged 20 to 40 and is associated with current cigarette smoking.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to your clinic with several months of worsening fatigue and dyspnea. She has not seen a healthcare professional in 10 years. She is also concerned about changes in the appearance of her fingernails. A photograph of her hands is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of her nail findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) with consequent pulmonary hypertension results in shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) and delivery of deoxygenated blood to the lower extremities. Chronic hypoxia in the lower extremities (seen initially as differential cyanosis) results in digital clubbing that selectively affects toenails (differential clubbing). Although pulmonary hypertension secondary to PDA can develop in this patient's age group and manifest with dyspnea, it would not cause digital clubbing of the fingernails.

B) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma causes episodic hypoxia due to acute lower airway obstructions. However, digital clubbing is a result of chronic hypoxia. Moreover, she lacks characteristic symptoms of bronchial asthma such as a persistent, dry cough with end-expiratory wheezes.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic iron deficiency anemia can cause concave spooning of the nail (koilonychia), but it is not associated with digital clubbing. The exact mechanism of koilonychia is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by disordered keratinization of the nail matrix secondary to iron deficiency. Although anemia could explain this patient's worsening fatigue, dyspnea usually occurs only on exertion. Moreover, additional signs, such as pallor, would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Nail changes in chronic psoriatic arthritis include nail pitting, onycholysis, nail-bed hyperkeratosis, and splinter hemorrhages. The condition is not associated with digital clubbing. Moreover, psoriatic arthritis would not explain this patient's fatigue and dyspnea.

E) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is the most common respiratory cause of digital clubbing in developed countries. The exact pathophysiology of clubbing is unknown but is thought to be the result of chronic hypoxia, which is seen in IPF due to a progressive destruction of pulmonary parenchyma. Hypoxia induces the release of vascular endothelial growth factor, which stimulates angiogenesis in the nail beds and increases blood flow. Additionally, platelet-derived growth factor released from megakaryocytes induces connective tissue proliferation. This fibrovascular proliferation appears as digital clubbing.

Key learning point: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a common cause of digital clubbing due to chronic hypoxia-induced fibrovascular proliferation in the nail beds.
questions.hint: This patient's fingers show digital clubbing, which is most commonly associated with prolonged hypoxia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 6-month history of shortness of breath and nonproductive cough. He has a 15-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily. On cardiopulmonary examination, you note fine inspiratory crackles bilaterally and clubbing of the fingers. Pulmonary function tests show an FVC of 78% of expected and an FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. A CT scan of the chest is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchiectasis can manifest with shortness of breath, cough, crackles on lung exam, and, rarely, clubbing. However, the cough of chronic bronchiectasis is typically productive of copious amounts of sputum and sometimes blood, which is not seen in this patient. In addition, PFTs in patients with chronic bronchiectasis most commonly show a pattern of obstructive lung disease rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient. Lastly, this patient's CT scan lacks the classic findings of chronic bronchiectasis, which include dilated, air-filled bronchi with irregular bronchial wall thickening.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis is the most likely diagnosis in this patient given his PFTs, imaging results, shortness of breath, persistent nonproductive cough, and bilateral fine inspiratory crackles, and clubbing (which suggests chronic hypoxia). PFTs in patients with pulmonary fibrosis most commonly show a pattern typical of restrictive lung disease, and the honeycombing seen on this patient's CT scan is also consistent with this diagnosis. Pulmonary fibrosis is most commonly idiopathic but can also be associated with certain risk factors, such as medication use (e.g., methotrexate, bleomycin, amiodarone), connective tissue disease (e.g., scleroderma), and environmental exposures (e.g., silicosis, coal dust exposure).

Key learning point: Pulmonary fibrosis presents with progressive dyspnea, nonproductive cough, fine inspiratory crackles, digital clubbing, restrictive lung pattern on PFTs, and honeycombing on chest imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis can occur in various forms, including allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA), chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, and invasive aspergillosis. Aspergillosis is rare, and this patient does not have any reported risk factors associated with aspergillosis (e.g., immunosuppression, preexisting lung disease), which makes this diagnosis very unlikely. In addition, PFTs in patients with ABPA typically show signs of obstructive lung disease, rather than restrictive lung disease, as seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary sarcoidosis can also manifest with shortness of breath, cough, and crackles on lung exam. However, clubbing is not a typical feature, and this patient does not have other symptoms of sarcoidosis (e.g., fever, malaise, weight loss) or any extrapulmonary findings of the disease (e.g., arthritis, anterior uveitis, erythema nodosum). In addition, while sarcoidosis can, in rare cases, manifest with a similar PFT pattern, normal findings are more common. Lastly, chest imaging in sarcoidosis is more likely to show extensive bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, which is not seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this patient may develop pulmonary hypertension as a result of his underlying condition, pulmonary hypertension alone would not cause this patient's symptoms, clinical findings, PFT abnormalities, and imaging study results.
questions.hint: A low FVC and high-normal FEV1/FVC ratio suggest a restrictive lung disease. Further expected findings would include a decreased DLCO.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the ED with progressive shortness of breath and mild pleuritic chest pain for 1 week. He has a 30-year history of construction and demolition work and quit smoking 5 years ago. Physical examination shows bibasilar fine crackles and mild digital clubbing. Chest x-ray demonstrates diffuse interstitial markings with calcified pleural plaques and a new right lower-lobe opacity. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Admit for bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
Initiate corticosteroid therapy for presumed pneumoconiosis flare
Obtain chest CT and arrange pulmonary follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bronchoscopy is not first-line in a patient with new symptoms and an opacity on imaging. The priority in the ED is to exclude infection or effusion using less invasive studies before considering bronchoscopy.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids have no role in treating pneumoconioses such as asbestosis or silicosis. The acute change in symptoms should prompt evaluation for infection or malignancy rather than empiric steroids.

C) INCORRECT:

New focal findings and acute symptom progression in an asbestos-exposed patient require immediate imaging. Simple reassurance and outpatient testing risk missing treatable infection or malignancy.

D) INCORRECT:

While heart failure can cause dyspnea, the chronic fibrotic pattern and pleural plaques point to pulmonary pathology. Diuretics would not address the likely cause and could delay appropriate evaluation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – In a patient with known asbestos exposure and new localized opacity, CT is indicated to differentiate superimposed infection from malignant transformation (e.g., mesothelioma or bronchogenic carcinoma). Pulmonary consultation should follow once emergent causes are excluded.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a 30-year history of sandblasting presents to the ED with shortness of breath. He complains of several weeks of worsening exertional dyspnea. He denies fever, chest pain, or hemoptysis. Vital signs are BP, 132/76 mm Hg; P, 96; R, 22; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F); oxygen saturation, 90% on room air. Chest x-ray shows numerous small, rounded opacities predominantly in the upper lobes and scattered ground-glass changes. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge with outpatient pulmonary function testing
Begin empiric antibiotic therapy for community-acquired pneumonia
Initiate bronchodilator therapy and discharge for outpatient COPD evaluation
Admit for empiric corticosteroid therapy for interstitial pneumonitis
Obtain high-resolution computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although pulmonary function testing is important for long-term management, this patient’s new hypoxemia and progressive dyspnea require further evaluation before discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

The chronic, nonproductive course and absence of fever or consolidation make bacterial pneumonia unlikely. Imaging suggests fibrotic occupational disease rather than infection.

C) INCORRECT:

While airflow limitation may coexist, the restrictive imaging pattern and hypoxemia suggest parenchymal fibrosis, not COPD. Bronchodilators are unlikely to address this patient’s symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not indicated for silicosis, which causes fibrotic rather than inflammatory lung disease. The acute concern is hypoxemia and possible superimposed infection or fibrosis progression, not inflammation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – In a patient with occupational silica exposure, characteristic upper-lobe nodularity, and new hypoxemia, chest CT helps distinguish progression of pneumoconiosis from superimposed infection (e.g., tuberculosis) or fibrosis with mass-like coalescence and helps guide disposition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 2-year history of progressive shortness of breath and a persistent dry cough. He finds it increasingly difficult to walk up a single flight of stairs without stopping. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history but quit 15 years ago. He has no history of connective tissue disease or significant occupational exposures. His vital signs are stable, with an oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Physical examination shows bibasilar, fine, end-inspiratory crackles and digital clubbing. A high-resolution CT scan of the chest shows subpleural, bibasilar reticular opacities with honeycombing. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention to improve this patient's functional capacity and quality of life?

choices.text: Enrollment in a pulmonary rehabilitation program
Initiation of long-term oral corticosteroid therapy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Referral for lung transplantation is an important consideration for eligible patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, as it is the only potentially curative therapy. However, it is a referral for evaluation, not a direct intervention to improve current functional capacity and quality of life. Furthermore, not all patients are candidates, and the process is lengthy.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonary rehabilitation is a comprehensive, evidence-based intervention that is a cornerstone of management for patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF). It consists of supervised exercise training, education, and psychosocial support. The primary goals are to improve functional exercise capacity, reduce the sensation of dyspnea, and enhance overall quality of life. For patients with chronic respiratory diseases like IPF, pulmonary rehabilitation has been shown to be one of the most effective non-pharmacologic treatments for improving daily function and well-being, regardless of the underlying disease severity. It should be offered to all symptomatic patients with IPF who are physically able to participate.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term oral corticosteroids are used in some forms of interstitial lung disease, particularly those with a prominent inflammatory component. However, in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, which is primarily a fibrotic process, large clinical trials have shown a lack of benefit and potential for harm with long-term steroid monotherapy. Their use is generally reserved for acute exacerbations.

D) INCORRECT:

Supplemental oxygen is indicated for patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis who have significant resting or exertional hypoxemia. This patient's resting oxygen saturation of 91% does not meet the standard criteria for continuous long-term oxygen therapy, which is typically an oxygen saturation of 88% or less. While he may require oxygen with exertion, a more comprehensive intervention is available to improve overall functional capacity.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is suggestive of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 9-month history of progressive shortness of breath with activity and a persistent dry cough. He does not have a fever, chest pain, or wheezing. He worked as an accountant and has no known occupational exposures. He previously smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 15 years ago. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 22/min. Oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Physical examination shows digital clubbing. Lung auscultation shows fine, bibasilar inspiratory crackles.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a chronic, progressive fibrosing interstitial pneumonia of unknown cause. It typically presents in adults over 60 with a history of smoking. The typical clinical features include an insidious onset of dyspnea on exertion and a persistent nonproductive cough over several months. Key physical examination findings are fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles, often described as sounding like velcro, and digital clubbing, which is present in about 50% of cases. The diagnosis is supported by the absence of other known causes of interstitial lung disease, such as environmental exposures or connective tissue disease. HRCT of the chest is the key diagnostic imaging modality.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis is an interstitial lung disease that can manifest with progressive dyspnea, cough, and crackles. However, it is caused by a prolonged immunologic response to an inhaled antigen, such as mold or avian proteins. This patient’s history as an accountant with no known occupational or environmental exposures makes this diagnosis less likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure is a common cause of dyspnea on exertion and bibasilar crackles due to pulmonary edema. However, the 9-month duration of a dry cough and the presence of digital clubbing are not typical features of heart failure. Additionally, other signs of volume overload, such as peripheral edema or jugular venous distention, are absent.

D) INCORRECT:

While sarcoidosis can cause pulmonary fibrosis with dyspnea and cough, it typically affects a younger population, often under the age of 40. Furthermore, digital clubbing is a rare finding in sarcoidosis. This patient’s age and the presence of clubbing make this diagnosis less likely than other possibilities.

E) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is a form of pulmonary fibrosis that can cause progressive dyspnea, bibasilar crackles, and digital clubbing. However, it is directly caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers, typically from occupations like shipbuilding, construction, or insulation work. This patient’s history as an accountant with no known occupational exposures makes asbestosis improbable.
questions.hint: The presence of a usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern on high-resolution CT (HRCT) is an expected finding in this condition.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 15-year history of progressive dyspnea on exertion and a chronic, nonproductive cough. He smoked a packet of cigarettes daily for 25 years, but quit 10 years ago. A chest x-ray shows numerous small, rounded opacities predominantly in the upper lung zones. Pulmonary function tests show a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern. Further history taking is most likely to reveal chronic exposure to which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Exposure to cotton dust causes byssinosis, an asthma-like syndrome. It is characterized by chest tightness and dyspnea that is classically worse at the beginning of the work week. This condition causes an obstructive pattern on pulmonary function tests and does not produce the fibrotic changes and rounded opacities seen on this patient's chest x-ray.

B) CORRECT:

Coal workers’ pneumoconiosis (CWP) results from chronic inhalation of coal dust, leading to the formation of coal macules (collections of dust-laden macrophages) in the lungs. Coal macules appear as small, rounded opacities on chest radiography, characteristically in the upper lung zones. Although a restrictive pattern can be seen due to fibrosis, a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern is common. The obstructive component can result from industrial bronchitis caused by the dust itself or from coexisting chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, which is likely in this patient given his smoking history. The clinical course of disease is typically insidious, with progressive dyspnea on exertion and chronic cough developing over many years.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic beryllium disease is a granulomatous pneumoconiosis that can cause progressive dyspnea. However, its radiographic findings typically include hilar lymphadenopathy and diffuse reticulonodular infiltrates, a pattern that differs from the predominantly upper-lobe rounded opacities described in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis is a plausible cause of progressive dyspnea due to occupational exposure. However, the characteristic radiographic findings of asbestosis include interstitial fibrosis and pleural plaques, with opacities predominantly affecting the lower lung zones, not the upper zones as in this patient.
questions.hint: Small, rounded opacities in the upper lung zones and a mixed obstructive/restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests are typical of this type of pneumoconiosis, which is associated with chronic bronchitis and risk of progressive massive fibrosis.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation comes to the physician for shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough that has persisted for 6 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His medications include warfarin, enalapril, and amiodarone. His pulse is 85/min and irregularly irregular. Physical examination shows enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails. A CT scan of the chest shows clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's dyspnea?

choices.text: Increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries
Fluid leak into the interstitium and alveoli
Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant neoplasm of the bronchus (i.e., bronchogenic carcinoma) is an important differential diagnosis in patients with an extensive smoking history (45 pack years) presenting with a chronic cough, dyspnea, fatigue, and nail clubbing. However, unlike the CT scan findings in this patient, a unilateral nodule or mass would be expected.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with lung carcinoma

A cavitary lesion containing an air-fluid level (red line) is seen in the right middle lobe, which is also opacified (green overlay) from air space consolidation. The consolidation abuts the minor fissure (black dashed line) and obscures the right heart border (silhouette sign).

The major diagnostic considerations for the cavitary lesion would include abscess or cavitary carcinoma.

White dashed line: approximate location of the right heart border

B) INCORRECT:

Increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries is seen in pulmonary hypertension, which is often asymptomatic but may manifest as dyspnea, fatigue, and nail clubbing, as seen in this patient. It also results in symptoms of cor pulmonale (e.g., chest pain and peripheral edema), which are absent in this patient. Unlike the CT scan findings in this patient, enlargement of the pulmonary trunk and arteries is typically evident in this condition.

Advanced stages of this patient's condition can result in pulmonary hypertension as well as cor pulmonale.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic airway inflammation and obstruction is the underlying mechanism of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which manifests with a persistent cough, dyspnea, and fatigue and is common in smokers. However, unlike the CT scan findings in this patient, alveolar septum destruction is evident in emphysema and bronchial wall thickening and enlarged vessels in chronic bronchitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchial hyperresponsiveness and obstruction is the underlying mechanism of asthma, which can also present with fatigue and dry cough. However, chest auscultation in patients with asthma typically reveals end-expiratory wheezes and clubbing is not typical. Radiographic imaging would show pulmonary hyperinflation (low, flattened diaphragm, wide intercostal spaces) rather than alveolar fibrosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluid leak into the interstitium and alveoli is the underlying mechanism of pulmonary edema, which can present with dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and crackles on chest auscultation, as seen in this patient. However, unlike the chronic course of this patient's illness, pulmonary edema typically has an acute presentation, with dyspnea that worsens in a supine position and signs of increased sympathetic tone (sweating, tachycardia). Furthermore, a CT scan would show perihilar pulmonary edema, basilar edema, and possibly Kerley B lines.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

F) INCORRECT:

Pleural scarring can occur as a consequence of benign pleural diseases (e.g., recurrent inflammation, recurrent pneumothoraces, asbestosis), or malignant pleural diseases (e.g., mesothelioma). Pleural diseases may present with exertional dyspnea and cough, as seen in this patient. However, unlike the CT scan findings in this patient, pleural thickening is typically evident in these conditions.
Image Description:

CT chest (with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with malignant mesothelioma

Nodular pleural thickening (hatched green overlay) encases the left lung and the volume of the left hemithorax (red dashed line) is reduced compared to the right (green dashed line). Enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes are present (red overlay).

The findings are compatible with malignant mesothelioma, although confluent pleural metastatic disease can have a similar appearance. Both primary and secondary pleural malignancies can cause pleural nodules, diffuse pleural thickening, and pleural effusion.

AO: aorta; LV: left ventricle; PA: pulmonary artery

G) CORRECT:

Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung is the underlying mechanism of this patient's interstitial lung disease. Diffuse thickening of the alveolar walls results in progressive fibrosis of the lung parenchyma, which in turn causes reduced vital capacity, and the dyspnea, chronic dry cough, and fatigue seen in this patient. While most cases are idiopathic (i.e., idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), this patient's exposure to amiodarone is the most likely cause.
Image Description:

CT chest (lung window; a: axial plane; b: coronal plane) of a patient with progressive dyspnea on exertion

Extensive reticular interstitial thickening with honeycombing (examples indicated by green outlines) is accompanied by traction bronchiectasis (examples indicated by red arrows). The distribution is subpleural and basal predominant. The appearance is diagnostic of a usual interstitial pneumonia pattern. There are no CT features to suggest an alternative diagnosis.

DA: descending aorta; H: heart
questions.hint: This patient's progressive dyspnea, dry cough, decreased exercise, and CT showing bibasilar reticular opacities are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis.
